content.webTitle: Mixed picture for teacher training courses

fields.headline: Mixed picture for teacher training courses
fields.bodyText: University teacher training courses for secondary schools have seen an increase in applications for biology, chemistry, art, languages and social studies this year, but falls in applications in mathematics, history and geography. The main increase in applications overall is for primary teacher training, which is up 13%, but there has also been an increase of 4% in the number applying for secondary teaching places. The rise in applications has come from both males and females, although women still make up the majority of those applying to the graduate teacher training registry. A total of 17,709 people applied for teacher training by 15 December 2000, the main deadline for courses starting in autumn 2001. This is an increase of 9.7% on the 16,145 who had applied by the same time the previous year. There are however wide variations is the numbers applying to different secondary school subjects. The biggest proportional increases have come in chemistry, modern languages and social studies, business studies and information technology, all of which saw applications up by over a third compared with last year. Applications in biology and art are also up by over a fifth. Applications however are down in French (-9.2%), history (-7.3%), geography (-5.6%), maths (-3.8%) and English (-2%). The biggest increase for primary teachers meanwhile is for those teaching 5-8 year olds, with applications up by just under 15% on last year. Women take up the majority of teacher training places, representing 13783 of the 17709 applications this year. This year the teacher training agency is offering £6,000 teacher training salaries and bonuses for teachers in England. An additional Ôgolden helloÕ of £4,000 is available for those working in.secondary shortage subjects - mathematics, science, modern foreign languages and technology.
